Same board and card as above, slightly newer kernel.
kernel and firmware as of 17.06.2012, no extra option in config.txt
Identical card to one above. One to look into, as I was expecting Arch to be faster...
CrystalDiskMark results (FAT32) This is my only card that can be counted on to boot up on each plug-in.
mmc0: note - long write sync 1453000ns - 14608 its. - kernel/module problems?
custom kernel from raspberrypi github - no more mmc0 sync problems
Had "long write sync" errors, slow boot times and then system instability using USB port on Macbook, switched to iPhone charger (5V 1A) and warning disappeared
(Same user / card as above, definitely notable that Raspbian is superior)
CrystalDiskMark results (FAT32) Card has no serial/is likely a fake.
After Hexxeh rpi-update. man:0x000003 oem:0x5344 name:SD08G hwrev:0x8 fwrev:0x0
"mmc0: error -84 whilst initialising SD card" at bootup, but works fine
After Hexxeh rpi-update. man:0x000003 oem:0x5344 name:SU16G hwrev:0x8 fwrev:0x0
Only boots with images with new firmware, didn't boot with previous images.
Tested with dd. Card doesn't maintain the promised minimum class speed.
Not sure why this setup is faster than others, test results repeatable.
Followed a forum post to install newest kernel from git repo.
Feels faster than my Kingston 4GB Class 4 card.
After installing new kernel with rpi-update on 2012-06-01
Same card as 'Lexar SDHC 16GB Class 10 "PLATINUM II"' above - imaged with Raspbian
TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {13153=Full hardware floating point on Raspbian (-mfloat-abi=hard -mfpu=vfp) and arm_freq=1000 and core_freq=500}
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {21487=Performance seems to improve considerably by dropping MTU from the default 1500 to 1488. However, this has caused kernel instabilities with Debian Squeeze images (debian6-19-04-2012). It is unknown if this performance benefit is also gained on other images, or if these kernel instabilities have been resolved.}
textBeforeTable: Depends on SD card used http://elinux.org/RaspberryPiBoardVerifiedPeripherals#SD_cards Results uname -a # find out which kernel you're running rm ~/test.tmp # cleanup dd if=~/test.tmp of=/dev/null bs=500K count=1024 # read dd if=/dev/zero of=~/test.tmp bs=500K count=1024 # write  Compile/Run Note: the dd test should probably use i/oflags=direct for reads and writes. But that will change the results recorded to date  TODO test SD card 335544320 bytes (336 MB) copied, 10.6428 s, 31.5 MB/s 10+0 records out 10+0 records in root@raspberrypi:~# dd if=/dev/sda of=/dev/null bs=32M count=10 iflag=direct A test with a fast USB-Stick showed that Raspberry Pi can achieve about 30 MB/s: All IO uses the same bus so the combination of all IO can not exceed the the bus speed of an as yet hypothetical 60MB/s USB bus IO 28.5fps armhf timedemo score: http://i.imgur.com/dUu0g.jpg armhf "driver info" : http://i.imgur.com/8nqa1.jpg 20.2fps armel timedemo score: http://i.imgur.com/i2TkN.jpg armel "driver info" : http://i.imgur.com/wtYhB.jpg Results \demo four \timedemo 1 - In-game console commands: - Bitdepth stuck at 16bpp, not sure how to change, values in q3config.cfg seem to be ignored - Runs at display's native res, in my case 1280x1024 - Start game - Download source, compile as delivered Compile/Run https://github.com/raspberrypi/quake3 Source ioquake3
